20.answer: To calculate the **inverse of a 2Ã2 matrix**, you can use a simple formula.  Letâs say your matrix is:  [ A = \begin{bmatrix} a & b \ c & d \end{bmatrix} ]  Then the **inverse matrix** ( A^{-1} ) is given by:  [ A^{-1} = \frac{1}{ad - bc} \begin{bmatrix} d & -b \ -c & a \end{bmatrix} ]  ---  ### â Steps  1. **Find the determinant**:    [    \text{det}(A) = ad - bc    ]    The determinant must be **non-zero**.    If ( ad - bc = 0 ), the matrix has **no inverse** (itâs *singular*).  2. **Swap** the elements on the main diagonal ( a \leftrightarrow d ).  3. **Change the signs** of the off-diagonal elements ( b ) and ( c ).  4. **Multiply** the resulting matrix by ( \frac{1}{\text{det}(A)} ).  ---  ### ð§® Example  If [ A = \begin{bmatrix} 2 & 5 \ 1 & 3 \end{bmatrix} ]  Then [ \text{det}(A) = (2)(3) - (5)(1) = 6 - 5 = 1 ]  So, [ A^{-1} = \frac{1}{1} \begin{bmatrix} 3 & -5 \ -1 & 2 \end{bmatrix} =============  \begin{bmatrix} 3 & -5 \ -1 & 2 \end{bmatrix} ]  ---  Would you like me to show how to compute it **programmatically** (e.g., in Python, C, or JavaScript)?
